Name: NDSA
Question: NDSA
Answer: National Digital Stewardship Alliance is a consortium of organizations (212, including, Digital Public Library of America, Yale University Library, and New York Public Library (NYPL)) committed to the long-term preservation of digital information.

Name: Levels of Preservation, Level 1
Question: Levels of Preservation, Level 1
Answer: Protect your data

Name: Levels of Preservation, Level 2
Question: Levels of Preservation, Level 2
Answer: Know your data

Name: Levels of Preservation, Level 3
Question: Levels of Preservation, Level 3
Answer: Monitor your data

Name: Levels of Preservation, Level 4
Question: Levels of Preservation, Level 4
Answer: Repair your data

Name: Level 1: Storage and Geographic Location
Question: Level 1: Storage and Geographic Location
Answer:
• Two complete copies that are not collocated.

  • For data on heterogeneous media (optical disks, hard drives, etc.) get the content off the medium and into your storage system.

Name: Level 2: Storage and Geographic Location
Question: Level 2: Storage and Geographic Location
Answer:
• At least three complete copies.

  • At least one copy in a different geographic location

  • Document your storage system(s) and storage media and what you need to use them.

Name: Level 3: Storage and Geographic Location
Question: Level 3: Storage and Geographic Location
Answer:
• A least one copy in a geographic location with a different disaster threat.

  • Obsolescence monitoring process for your storage system(s) and media.

Name: Level 4: Storage and Geographic Location
Question: Level 4: Storage and Geographic Location
Answer:
• At least three copies in geographic locations with different disaster threats.

  • Have a comprehensive plan in place that will keep files and metadata on currently accessible media or systems.

Name: Level 1: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Question: Level 1: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Answer:
• Check file fixity on ingest if it has been provided with the content.

  • Create fixity info if it wasn't provided with the content.

Name: Level 2: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Question: Level 2: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Answer:
• Check fixity on all ingests.

  • Use write blockers when working with original media.

  • Virus-check high risk content.

Name: Level 3: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Question: Level 3: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Answer:
• Check fixity of content at fixed intervals.

  • Maintain logs of fixity info; supply audit on demand.

  • Ability to detect corrupt data.

  • Virus-check all content.

Name: Level 4: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Question: Level 4: File Fixity and Data Integrity
Answer:
• Check fixity of all content in response to specific events or activities.

  • Ability to replace/repair corrupted data.

  • Ensure no one person has write access to all copies.

Name: Level 1: Information Security
Question: Level 1: Information Security
Answer:
• Identify who has read, write, move, and delete authorization to individual files.

  • Restrict who has those authorizations to individual files.

Name: Level 2: Information Security
Question: Level 2: Information Security
Answer: Document access restrictions for content.

Name: Level 3: Information Security
Question: Level 3: Information Security
Answer: Maintain logs of who performed what actions on files, including deletions and preservation actions.

Name: Level 4: Information Security
Question: Level 4: Information Security
Answer: Perform audit logs.

Name: Level 1: Metadata
Question: Level 1: Metadata
Answer:
• Inventory of content and its storage locations.

  • Ensure backup and non-collocation of inventory.

Name: Level 2: Metadata
Question: Level 2: Metadata
Answer:
• Store administrative metadata.

  • Store transformative metadata and log events.

Name: Level 3: Metadata
Question: Level 3: Metadata
Answer: Store standard technical and descriptive metadata.

Name: Level 4: Metadata
Question: Level 4: Metadata
Answer: Store standard preservation metadata.

Name: Level 1: File Formats
Question: Level 1: File Formats
Answer: When you can give input into the creation of digital files envourage use of a limited set of known open formats and codecs.

Name: Level 2: File Formats
Question: Level 2: File Formats
Answer: Inventory of file formats in use.

Name: Level 3: File Formats
Question: Level 3: File Formats
Answer: Monitor file format obsolescence issues.

Name: Level 4: File Formats
Question: Level 4: File Formats
Answer: Perform format migrations, emulation and similar activities as needed.
